Sahansaho is a joint project coordinated by the Finnish Somalia Network (FSN) addressing the sustainable use and management of the natural resources in Somalia. The key development problem which the project aims to find solutions to is the desertification leading to loss of livelihoods poverty and forced migration. The project is implemented at 3 sites in northern and central Somalia with the FSN's four partners in Finland and three partners in Somalia. The innovative cooperative model enforces the civil so ciety in Somalia and creates new networks promoting in that way peace and stability. As an environmental project it promotes also climate sustainability.The long-term objective is the secured livelihood of the communities and the restored vegetation cover in the project areas. The project has been planned for 10 years (1 + 3x3 y) and this continuous project will be the second 3-year phase. The immediate objectives of the next phase are:1. Soil and water conservation enhanced2. Pressure on natural vegetation decreased3. Existing environmental centers developed into regional hubs4. Collaboration and partnerships between local national and international actors in environmental sector strengthenedThe beneficiaries include the partner NGOs 1500 households communi ty members farmers and women participating in trainings regional administrations school children and teachers. The final beneficiaries are the local communities at large that benefit from the rising awareness on environmental issues and finally from the be tter condition of the environment which will improve their livelihood in general. The project promotes gender equality by enabling the participation of women in the trainings and activities. The poorest people in poor fragile states feel the negative impac ts of climate change most severely. By finding sustainable solutions to the environment problems and by helping people to adapt to the climate change the project thus reduces inequality considerably. The reduction of inequality is also taken into considera tion by enabling local minority groups who are sometimes discriminated to participate in the trainings and to benefit from the project?s results. The main activities include tree seedling production and tree product development agroforestry practices water harvesting energy saving stove promotion trainings and facilitation of the environmental policy development.
